elements.content: The preparation, structural characterization and magnetic investigation of three new cobalt(II) complexes of formula [Co2(bta)(H2O)8] n ·4nH2O (1 and 2) and [Co2(bta)(H2O)8] n ·2nH2O (3) (H4bta = 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylic acid) are reported. The crystal structures of 1−3 consist of neutral square-grids of high-spin cobalt(II) ions with the fully deprotonated bta4− anion acting as a 4-fold connector. The interpenetration of two of these layers in 3 leads to a three-dimensional network. Each cobalt atom in 1−3 is six-coordinated with two carboxylate-oxygen atoms from two bta ligands in trans positions and four water molecules building somewhat distorted octahedral surroundings. Extensive hydrogen bonding involving the noncoordinated carboxylate-oxygens and the coordinated and crystallization water molecules afford three-dimensional supramolecular networks in all three compounds. The values of the intralayer cobalt−cobalt separations through cis- and trans-coordinated carboxylate groups are 6.6831(16) and 11.339(2) Å for 1, and 6.682(4) and 11.329(5) Å for 2 and 6.7801(5)/6.7705(3) and 11.3923(4)/11.2952(3) Å for (3). Magnetic susceptibility measurements of polycrystalline samples of 1−3 in the temperature range 1.9−295 K show the occurrence of very weak antiferromagnetic interactions between the high-spin cobalt(II) ions, the strong decrease of χM T upon cooling being mainly due to the depopulation of the higher Kramers doublets of the six-coordinated cobalt(II) ions.

elements.content: There has been considerable interest in porous metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) with regular and accessible cavities in recent years. Although the aims of this research field concern the discovery and synthesis of new materials for practical applications that use their functional aspects, including magnetism, catalysis, storage, separation, sensors, and electronics, it is clear that the understanding of the structural aspects of such materials is a key point to achieve a significant progress. At this respect, the bridging ligand is of outmost importance because it greatly influences the structures of the metal assemblies. In fact, polycarboxylate-type ligands are among the most widely used linkers of metal ions in the design of polynuclear complexes with interesting magnetic properties. The coordination chemistry of aromatic polycarboxylate-transition metal complexes attracts considerable interest in inorganic chemistry and in materials science. So far some of the supramolecular structures based on one of the multidentate aromatic polycarboxylate bridging ligands such as the rigid 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate, 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate, 1,2,4-benzenetricarboxylate and 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylate (fully deprotonated form of H4bta), have been reported. The partially or fully deprotonated forms of H4bta may adopt a large variety of coordination modes in their reactions with metal ions. Moreover, they can act not only as hydrogen-bond acceptors but also as hydrogen-bond donors to form supramolecular structures or allowed guest structures by hydrogen bonding interactions.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

There has been considerable interest in porous metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) with regular and accessible cavities in recent years. Although the aims of this research field concern the discovery and synthesis of new materials for practical applications that use their functional aspects, including magnetism, catalysis, storage, separation, sensors, and electronics, it is clear that the understanding of the structural aspects of such materials is a key point to achieve a significant progress. At this respect, the bridging ligand is of outmost importance because it greatly influences the structures of the metal assemblies. In fact, polycarboxylate-type ligands are among the most widely used linkers of metal ions in the design of polynuclear complexes with interesting magnetic properties. The coordination chemistry of aromatic polycarboxylate-transition metal complexes attracts considerable interest in inorganic chemistry and in materials science. So far some of the supramolecular structures based on one of the multidentate aromatic polycarboxylate bridging ligands such as the rigid 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate, 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate, 1,2,4-benzenetricarboxylate and 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylate (fully deprotonated form of H4bta), have been reported. The partially or fully deprotonated forms of H4bta may adopt a large variety of coordination modes in their reactions with metal ions. Moreover, they can act not only as hydrogen-bond acceptors but also as hydrogen-bond donors to form supramolecular structures or allowed guest structures by hydrogen bonding interactions.

elements.content: The presence of water molecules in most of these compounds can play an important role in the crystal stabilization, due to their ability to form H-bonds with the host structure. On the other hand, water could play a space filling role in the cases where there are cavities or pores of a suitable size in the metal-organic framework. However, it is rare for water molecules present in porous crystals not to be strongly H-bonded to some groups on the host organic molecules. Therefore, the H-bonded water molecules significantly contribute to the total lattice energy, and to the stability of the hydrated crystal structure.

However, it is rare for water molecules present in porous crystals not to be strongly H-bonded to some groups on the host organic molecules. Therefore, the H-bonded water molecules significantly contribute to the total lattice energy, and to the stability of the hydrated crystal structure.

elements.content: The framework of a metal-organic crystal host offers an alternative environment for stabilizing various topologies of water aggregates. Both experimental data and theoretical studies strongly suggest that the tri-, tetra-, and pentameric water motifs have cyclic, quasi-planar minimum energy structures. An average O···O distance covering the range 2.743−2.880 Å is calculated for cyclic tetrameric water units. Herein we describe the formation of square water motifs and their self-assembly along the channels of an unprecedented metal-organic crystal host in a series of bta-containing cobalt(II) complexes of formula [Co2(bta)(H2O)8] n ·4nH2O (1 and 2) and [Co2(bta)(H2O)8] n ·2nH2O (3) where the cobalt atom and the bta4− ligand act as simple linear node and 4-fold connector, respectively. The synthesis, crystal structure determination and variable-temperature magnetic investigation of 1−3 are reported here.

An average O⋅⋅⋅O distance covering the range 2.743-2.880 Å is calculated for cyclic tetrameric water units. Herein we describe the formation of square water motifs and their self-assembly along the channels of an unprecedented metal-organic crystal host in a series of bta-containing cobalt(II) complexes of formula [Co2(bta)(H2O)8] n ⋅4nH2O (1 and 2) and [Co2(bta)(H2O)8] n ⋅2nH2O (3) where the cobalt atom and the bta4- ligand act as simple linear node and 4-fold connector, respectively. The synthesis, crystal structure determination and variable-temperature magnetic investigation of 1-3 are reported here.

elements.content: Reagents and solvents used in the syntheses of 1−3 were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification. Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were performed with an EA 1108 CHNS/0 automatic analyzer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

Reagents and solvents used in the syntheses of 1-3 were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification. Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were performed with an EA 1108 CHNS/0 automatic analyzer.

elements.content: Single crystals of 1 were grown by slow diffusion using the gel technique. An aqueous solution of NaOH (0.5 M) was added dropwise to another aqueous solution (5 cm3) of H4bta (0.127 g, 0.5 mmol) until a value of pH = 4.5 was reached. Then, tetramethoxysilane (0.25 cm3) was added to the previous solution under vigorous stirring. The gel was formed after standing 1 day at room temperature. An aqueous solution (3 cm3) of CoCl2·6H2O (0.119 g, 0.5 mmol) was carefully added over the gel. Prismatic pink crystals of 1 were grown at room temperature after several weeks. They were mechanically separated, washed with 50/50 water/methanol solution, and air-dried. Anal. Calcd. for C10H26Co2O20 (1): C, 17.11; H, 3.71. Found: C, 17.05; H, 3.67%.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of the Complexes

[Co2(bta)(H2O)8] n ⋅4nH2O (1)

Single crystals of 1 were grown by slow diffusion using the gel technique. An aqueous solution of NaOH (0.5 M) was added dropwise to another aqueous solution (5 cm3) of H4bta (0.127 g, 0.5 mmol) until a value of pH = 4.5 was reached. Then, tetramethoxysilane (0.25 cm3) was added to the previous solution under vigorous stirring. The gel was formed after standing 1 day at room temperature. An aqueous solution (3 cm3) of CoCl2⋅6H2O (0.119 g, 0.5 mmol) was carefully added over the gel. Prismatic pink crystals of 1 were grown at room temperature after several weeks. They were mechanically separated, washed with 50/50 water/methanol solution, and air-dried. Anal. Calcd. for C10H26Co2O20 (1): C, 17.11; H, 3.71. Found: C, 17.05; H, 3.67%.

elements.content: This compound was obtained by following a procedure similar to that used for 1 but changing the pH to 5.0. Prismatic pink crystals of 2 were formed after a few weeks on standing at room temperature. They were mechanically separated, washed with a 50/50 water/methanol solution, and air-dried. Anal. Calcd. for C10H26Co2O20 (2): C, 17.11; H, 3.71. Found: C, 17.04; H, 3.68%.

elements.content: Aqueous solutions of H4bta (0.12 g, 0.5 mmol) and sodium carbonate (0.10 g, 1 mmol) were mixed (total volume 55 cm3). The cobalt(II) chloride hexahydrate (0.119 g, 0.5 mmol) dissolved in a minimum amount of water was added to the previous solution under vigorous stirring. The resulting clear solution was allowed to evaporate under controlled temperature at ca. 50 °C. X-ray quality crystals of 3 as pink needles were obtained after two days. Anal. Calcd. for C10H22Co2O18 (3): C, 18.04; H, 3.30. Found: C, 17.95; H, 3.26%.

elements.content: Magnetic susceptibility measurements on polycrystalline samples of compounds 1−3 were carried out in the temperature range 1.9−300 K with a Quantum Design SQUID magnetometer under an applied magnetic field of 250 G. Corrections for the diamagnetic contribution of the constituent atoms and for the magnetization of the sample holder were done.
elements.clean_text:
Physical Measurements

Magnetic susceptibility measurements on polycrystalline samples of compounds 1-3 were carried out in the temperature range 1.9-300 K with a Quantum Design SQUID magnetometer under an applied magnetic field of 250 G. Corrections for the diamagnetic contribution of the constituent atoms and for the magnetization of the sample holder were done.

elements.content: X-ray diffraction data for single crystals of 1 and 3 were collected at 300 K on a Nonius Kappa CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (0.71073 Å), whereas those of 2 were collected at the ESRF synchrotron BM16 beamline (Grenoble, France) using λ = 0.7293 Å at 100 K. Data were indexed, integrated, and scaled using the EVALCCD (1) and HKL2000 (2) programs. The crystal of compound 3 was a non-merohedral twin. The reflections for both components of the twin were indexed using DIRAX and integrated through the EVALCCD. The equivalent reflections were merged using the TWINABS, program suite. The twin refinement was performed with SHELXL97 using the HKLF4 data for the solution and the HKLF5 format for the refinement, including the TWIN and BASF statements. All the reflections having at least one contribution from the major component have been used for the HKLF5 refinement. The BASF factor in the final refinement of 3 gives a value of 0.5240, leading to percentages of 52.4(1) and 47.6(1) for each one of the twin domains. The structures of 1−3 were solved by direct methods using the SHELXS97 computational program. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically by full-matrix least-squares technique based on F 2 using SHELXL97. The hydrogen atoms of 1 and 3 (except those of the water molecules) were positioned geometrically and refined with a riding model. All the hydrogen atoms for 2 were located from Fourier difference maps and refined with isotropic temperature factors.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure Determination and Refinement

X-ray diffraction data for single crystals of 1 and 3 were collected at 300 K on a Nonius Kappa CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (0.71073 Å), whereas those of 2 were collected at the ESRF synchrotron BM16 beamline (Grenoble, France) using λ = 0.7293 Å at 100 K. Data were indexed, integrated, and scaled using the EVALCCD (1) and HKL2000 (2) programs. The crystal of compound 3 was a non-merohedral twin. The reflections for both components of the twin were indexed using DIRAX and integrated through the EVALCCD. The equivalent reflections were merged using the TWINABS, program suite. The twin refinement was performed with SHELXL97 using the HKLF4 data for the solution and the HKLF5 format for the refinement, including the TWIN and BASF statements. All the reflections having at least one contribution from the major component have been used for the HKLF5 refinement. The BASF factor in the final refinement of 3 gives a value of 0.5240, leading to percentages of 52.4(1) and 47.6(1) for each one of the twin domains. The structures of 1-3 were solved by direct methods using the SHELXS97 computational program. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically by full-matrix least-squares technique based on F 2 using SHELXL97. The hydrogen atoms of 1 and 3 (except those of the water molecules) were positioned geometrically and refined with a riding model. All the hydrogen atoms for 2 were located from Fourier difference maps and refined with isotropic temperature factors.

The structure of 1 consists of (4,4) square grid layers of cobalt atoms that grow in the bc crystallographic plane. The fully deprotonated bta4− anion connects four [Co(H2O)4]2+ cations through its four carboxylate groups acting as a 4-fold connector, whereas the tetraaquacobalt(II) units act as linear nodes (Figure a). The layers are regularly stacked along the a direction building up a porous structure [the pore size defined by the cobalt−cobalt separations of adjacent cobalt atms within each layer is 11.478(3) × 11.339(2) Å2]. The total potential solvent accessible void volume is 130.9 Å3, that is, about 24.1% per unit cell. The (4,4) layers are interconnected through extensive hydrogen bonds involving the carboxylate-oxygen atoms and the coordination and crystallization water molecules (see end of Table ) affording a three-dimensional supramolecular network (Figure b). The distance between neighboring layers is 5.4287(11) Å.

Crystallographic data for the structures 1-3 have been deposited at the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre with CCDC reference numbers 256557(1), 692490(2), and 701668(3), respectively.

Results and Discussion

Description of the Structures

[Co2(bta)(H2O)8] n ⋅4nH2O (1)

The structure of 1 consists of (4,4) square grid layers of cobalt atoms that grow in the bc crystallographic plane. The fully deprotonated bta4- anion connects four [Co(H2O)4]2+ cations through its four carboxylate groups acting as a 4-fold connector, whereas the tetraaquacobalt(II) units act as linear nodes (Figure a). The layers are regularly stacked along the a direction building up a porous structure [the pore size defined by the cobalt-cobalt separations of adjacent cobalt atms within each layer is 11.478(3) × 11.339(2) Å2]. The total potential solvent accessible void volume is 130.9 Å3, that is, about 24.1% per unit cell. The (4,4) layers are interconnected through extensive hydrogen bonds involving the carboxylate-oxygen atoms and the coordination and crystallization water molecules (see end of Table ) affording a three-dimensional supramolecular network (Figure b). The distance between neighboring layers is 5.4287(11) Å.

elements.content: Two crystallographically independent cobalt atoms [Co(1) and Co(2)] occur in 1 (Figure ). Both are six-coordinated with four water molecules and two carboxylate-oxygen atoms building a somewhat distorted octahedral environment5 with geometric values of ϕ = 60.70° [Co(1)] and 59.72° [Co(2)] and s/h = 1.21 [Co(1)] and 1.23 [Co(2)] (ϕ = 60° and s/h = 1.22 for an ideal octahedral environment). These values show that the cobalt atoms exhibit slightly compressed [Co(1)] and elongated [Co(2)] octahedral environments. The equatorial plane of the Co(1) ion is built up by two water molecules [O(1w) and O(1w)l-1] and two carboxylate-oxygen atoms [O(1) and O(1)l-1; (l-1) = −x, −1 − y, 1 − z], whereas other two coordination water molecules [O(2w) and O(2w)l-1] fill the axial sites. Four water molecules [O(3w), O(4w), O(3w)m-1 and O(4w)m-1; (m-1) = −x, −y, 2 − z] build the equatorial plane around Co(2), the axial positions being occupied by two carboxylate-oxygen atoms [O(3) and O(3)m-1]. The Co−Ow and Co−Obta bond lengths are in agreement with those observed in the [Co(H2O)6]2+ cation and in bta-containing cobalt(II) complexes. The mean value of the equatorial Co−O bond lengths is 2.109(3) Å for Co(1) and 2.087(3) Å for Co(2), values which are somewhat longer [2.065(4) Å for Co(1)]/shorter [2.100(2) Å for Co(2)] than the axial bond lengths for the compressed/elongated octahedral environments, respectively (see Table ).

elements.content: The bta4− group in 1 has an inversion center located in the middle of the benzene ring and it acts as a tetrakis-monodentate ligand being bound to the cobalt atoms Co(1), Co(2), Co(1)o-1 and Co(2)p-1 through the carboxylate-oxygens O(1), O(3), O(1)n-1 and O(3)n-1 respectively [symmetry code: (n-1) = 1 − x, −1 − y, 2 − z; (o-1) = 1 + x, y, 1 + z; (p-1) = 1 + x, 1 − y, z]. The average values for the coordinated and free carbonyl-oxygen atoms are quite similar [1.2652(2) and 1.24461(3) Å, respectively]. The values of the dihedral angle between the mean plane defined by the benzene ring and the planes of the carboxylate groups are 31.571(6) and 59.720(11)°. The internal angles in the benzene ring for the substituted carbon atoms [average value of 119.08(2)°] are slightly smaller than those for the nonsubstituted carbon atoms [119.32(2)°].

The average values for the coordinated and free carbonyl-oxygen atoms are quite similar [1.2652(2) and 1.24461(3) Å, respectively]. The internal angles in the benzene ring for the substituted carbon atoms [average value of 119.08(2)°] are slightly smaller than those for the nonsubstituted carbon atoms [119.32(2)°].

elements.content: The presence of coordinated and crystallization water molecules in 1 (eight plus four respectively, per two cobalt atoms) leads to an extensive hydrogen-bonded network (see end of Table ). The uncoordinated water molecules [O(5wA), O(6wA), O(5wB) and O(8wB)] have a shared occupation factor, and thus several arrangements of the water molecules are possible. They are depicted in Scheme . The building block for all the conformations is a square of four water molecules with a parallel stacking along the a axis (A conformation), opposite edge sharing to form a ladder-like chain (B conformation), regular alternating of mutually perpendicular square units (C conformation) or the corresponding random mixture (D conformation). The square water units parallel to the covalent network (those of the A conformation) are generated by an inversion center located in the middle of the square operating on two water molecules [O(5wA) and O(6wA)]. The squares are stacked along the a direction, with a separation between adjacent motifs of 5.4287(10) Å. The water ladders located perpendicularly to the covalent network (B conformation) are generated in the same way as those of the A conformation but through the O(5wB) and O(6wB) water molecules. Since both sets of water molecules [O(5wA), O(6wA) and O(5wB), O(8wB)] occur in this crystal structure, a mixture of the A and B conformations is expected. The random conformation (D) of the water molecules among the pores of the structure of 1 is the best description of the water arrangements.

elements.content: The structure of 2 consists of two crystallographically independent parallel (4,4) square grid layers that grow in the bc crystallographic plane similar to that observed in 1. In fact, 2 and 1 are polymorphs. They are built up by fully deprotonated bta4− anions acting as 4-fold connectors and [Co(H2O)4]2+ cations acting as linear nodes (Figure a). The layers are stacked along the a direction following the ABAB sequence, leading to the formation of pores of dimension 11.483(3) × 11.329(5) Å2 [defined by the distance between adjacent cobalt atoms within the two layers]. The total potential solvent accessible void volume is 274.0 Å3 which represents a 25.3% of the unit cell. The distance between adjacent layers is 5.4235(10) Å, a value which is similar to that observed for compound 1. The layers are interconnected through extensive hydrogen bonds involving some of the carboxylate-oxygen atoms, and the coordination and the crystallization water molecules (see end of Table ) to afford a 3D supramolecular network Figure b).

The structure of 2 consists of two crystallographically independent parallel (4,4) square grid layers that grow in the bc crystallographic plane similar to that observed in 1. In fact, 2 and 1 are polymorphs. They are built up by fully deprotonated bta4- anions acting as 4-fold connectors and [Co(H2O)4]2+ cations acting as linear nodes (Figure a). The layers are stacked along the a direction following the ABAB sequence, leading to the formation of pores of dimension 11.483(3) × 11.329(5) Å2 [defined by the distance between adjacent cobalt atoms within the two layers]. The total potential solvent accessible void volume is 274.0 Å3 which represents a 25.3% of the unit cell. The distance between adjacent layers is 5.4235(10) Å, a value which is similar to that observed for compound 1. The layers are interconnected through extensive hydrogen bonds involving some of the carboxylate-oxygen atoms, and the coordination and the crystallization water molecules (see end of Table ) to afford a 3D supramolecular network Figure b).

Four crystallographically independent cobalt(II) ions [Co(1), Co(2), Co(3) and Co(4)] occur in 2, all of them laying on crystallographic inversion centers (Figure ). They are six-coordinated, four water molecules and two carboxylate-oxygen atoms building slightly elongated [Co(1) and Co(2)] and compressed [Co(3) and Co(4)] octahedral environments with geometric values of ϕ = 59.33° [Co(1)], 59.483° [Co(2)], 60.48° [Co(3)] and 60.41° [Co(4)] and s/h = 1.24 [Co(1)], 1.23 [Co(2)], 1.19 [Co(3)] and 1.21 [Co(4)]. Four water molecules [O(1w), O(2w) and their symmetry related ones] build up the equatorial plane around Co(1). A water molecule, a carboxylate-oxygen and their symmetry related atoms through the inversion center define the equatorial plane around Co(2) [O(3) and O(4w)], Co(3) [O(5) and O(6w)] and Co(4) [O(7) and O(7w)]. The axial positions at Co(1) are filled by two carboxylate-oxygens [O(1) and the symmetry related atom], while those at Co(2), Co(3) and Co(4) are occupied by coordination water molecules [O(3w), O(5w), O(8w) and those related by the −1 symmetry operator at Co(2), Co(3) and Co(4), respectively]. The mean values of the equatorial Co−O bond lengths are 2.0854(11) [Co(1)], 2.0862(12) [Co(2)], 2.1223(10) [Co(3)] and 2.1045(12) Å [Co(4)]; they are all are somewhat shorter than the axial bond distances for Co(1) and Co(2) [2.1251(9) and 2.1175(11) Å, respectively] and slightly longer than those for Co(3) and Co(4) [2.0430(13) and 2.0696(10) Å, respectively] (see Table ).

elements.content: There are two crystallographically independent bta4− groups in 2, hereafter noted bta(1) [O(1), O(2), O(3), O(4), C(1), C(2), C(3), C(4) and C(5)] and bta(2) [O(5), O(6), O(7), O(8), C(6), C(7), C(8), C(9) and C(10)]. Each bta ligand is formed by the application of an inversion center located in the center of each benzene ring. As in 1, both bta4− groups adopt a tetrakis-monodentate coordination mode linking four cobalt atoms [through O(1) and O(3) from bta(1) toward Co(1) and Co(2) and through O(5) and O(7) from bta(2) toward Co(3) and O(7)]. The average values of the C−O bond lengths for the coordinated and free carbonyl-oxygen atoms are quite similar [1.269(3) and 1.248(4) Å for bta(1) and 1.268(3) and 1.245(4) Å for bta(2)]. The values of the dihedral angle between the mean plane defined by the benzene ring and the planes of the carboxylate groups in 2 are similar to those of 1 [31.1(2) and 59.1(2)° for bta(1) and 31.4(2) and 60.8(2)° for bta(2)]. The internal angles in the benzene ring for the substituted carbon atoms [average values of 118.5(3) and 118.7(3)° for bta(1) and bta(2), respectively] are slightly smaller than those for the nonsubstituted carbon atoms [122.1(3) and 122.6(3)° for bta(1) and bta(2), respectively].

elements.content: As in 1, an extensive hydrogen-bonded network occurs in 2 which is due to the presence of eight coordinated and four crystallization water molecules per each [Co2(bta)] unit. All water molecules are involved in hydrogen bonds between themselves or with carboxylate oxygen atoms. The crystallization water molecules [O(9w), O(10w), O(11w) and O(12w)] build up two perpendicular and planar square water clusters formed by the application of an inversion center which is located in the middle of each square water motif. They are regularly repeated along the a axis filling the hydrophilic pores of the structure (see Figure ). The angle between the adjacent square water motifs is 86.76(3)° and the shortest distance between crystallization water molecules from adjacent squares is 4.220(2) Å. Due to the high redundancy of the X-ray data for this complex, the hydrogen atoms of the crystallization water molecules could be located from Fourier differences. This feature gives reliability over the values of the hydrogen bonds for the anchoring scheme of the square water units to the host structure (see end of Table ).

elements.content: The structure of complex 3 consists of a three-dimensional network made up of 2-fold interpenetrated (4,4) square layers growing in the ab and bc the planes and crystallization water molecules. The bc layers are regularly stacked along the a direction while the ab layers do it along the c direction but following the ABAB sequence. The B layers are related to the A ones by a 2-fold rotation axis along the b direction. The layers are quite similar to those observed in 1 and 2, they are built up from two crystallographically independent [Co2(bta)] units leading to two nonsymmetrically related two-dimensional networks (Figure ). The (4,4) networks in 3 are constructed by 4-fold connectors [the fully deprotonated bta4− anions] and linear nodes [the [Co(H2O)4]2+ cations], as in 1 and 2.

The structure of complex 3 consists of a three-dimensional network made up of 2-fold interpenetrated (4,4) square layers growing in the ab and bc the planes and crystallization water molecules. The bc layers are regularly stacked along the a direction while the ab layers do it along the c direction but following the ABAB sequence. The B layers are related to the A ones by a 2-fold rotation axis along the b direction. The layers are quite similar to those observed in 1 and 2, they are built up from two crystallographically independent [Co2(bta)] units leading to two nonsymmetrically related two-dimensional networks (Figure ). The (4,4) networks in 3 are constructed by 4-fold connectors [the fully deprotonated bta4- anions] and linear nodes [the [Co(H2O)4]2+ cations], as in 1 and 2.

elements.content: The structure of 3, compared to those of 1 and 2, exhibits a more efficient packing leading to a reduction of the number of crystallization water molecules anchored in the pores. These molecules link the 2-fold interpenetrated square layers through hydrogen bonds, contributing to the stabilization of the 3D structure (see end of Table ). The total potential solvent accessible void volume in 3 is 693.6 Å3, that is a 17.1% lower per unit cell than that observed in 1 and 2, as expected.

The total potential solvent accessible void volume in 3 is 693.6 Å3, that is a 17.1% lower per unit cell than that observed in 1 and 2, as expected.

Three crystallographically independent cobalt atoms [Co(1), Co(2) and Co(3)] occur in 3, two of them lying on an inversion center (see Figure ). Each cobalt atom exhibits an elongated octahedral environment with geometric values of ϕ and s/h of 1.25 and 58.62° [Co(1)], 1.24 and 59.25° [Co(2)] and 1.25 and 58.97° [Co(3)]. The equatorial planes of the cobalt atoms are built by two water molecules [O(2w) and O(4w) (Co(1)), O(6w) and O(6w)i-3 (Co(2)) and O(7w) and O(7w)j-3 (Co(3)); (i-3) = 1 − x, −y, −z and (j-3) = 1 − x, 1 − y, −z] and two carboxylate-oxygen atoms [O(3) and O(1)b-3 (Co(1)), O(5) and O(5)i-3 (Co(2)) and O(7) and O(7)j-3 (Co(3))], whereas the axial positions are filled by two water molecules [O(1w) and O(3w) (Co(1)), O(5w) and O(5w)i-3 (Co(2)) and O(8w) and O(8w)j-3 (Co(3))]. The mean values of the equatorial Co−O bond lengths are 2.0714(14), 2.0773(14) and 2.0761(15) Å for Co(1), Co(2) and Co(3), respectively. These values are somewhat smaller than the average axial bond lengths [2.1583(15) (Co(1)), 2.122(2) (Co(2)), and 2.1425(15) Å (Co(3))] (see Table ).

elements.content: The two crystallographically independent (bta)4− groups in 3 [bta(1) and bta(2) corresponding to the O(1)O(2)O(3)O(4)C(1)C(2)C(3)C(4)C(5) and O(5)O(6)O(7)O(8)C(6)C(7)C(8)C(9)C(10) sets of atoms] are generated by an inversion center located in the middle of the aromatic rings. As observed in 1 and 2, the bta ligands in 3 adopt a tetrakis-monodentate coordination mode. The average C−O bond lengths for the coordinated and free carboxylate-oxygen atoms are quite similar 1.266(3) and 1.248(2) Å [bta(1)] and 1.255(4) and 1.245(4) Å [bta(2)]. The dihedral angles between the mean plane defined by the benzene ring of the bta ligand and the planes of carboxylate groups are 63.00(7) and 28.88(12)° for bta(1) and 62.18(2) and 25.60(9)° for bta(2), values which are in good agreement with those reported for complexes 1 and 2.

elements.content:
The values of the internal angles of the benzene rings are slightly smaller for the substituted carbon atoms than for the nonsubstituted ones [average values of 119.1(2)° and 121.7(2)°].

The values of the intralayer cobalt−cobalt separations through the trans carboxylate-bta groups are 11.3923(4) (A) and 11.2952(3) Å (B). They are much longer than the shortest inter- [4.9387(4) Å for Co(1)···Co(3)a-3] and intralayer [6.7801(5) Å for Co(1)···Co(1)e-3 (A) and 6.7705(3) Å for Co(2)···Co(3) (B) both through the cis-bta carboxylate-groups metal−metal distances. It deserves to be noted that the shortest intermolecular cobalt···cobalt distances between two parallel layers in 3 are 8.7866(5) Å for Co(1)···Co(1)k-3 and 9.0320(2) Å for Co(2)···Co(2)a-3 [(k-3) = −x, y, 0.5 − z], values which are greater that the metal−metal separation between two adjacent layers in 1 [5.4287(11) Å] and 2 [5.4235(10) Å].

elements.content: The polycarboxylic acids adopt a wide range of coordination modes in their metal complexes. This article focuses on specific examples of cobalt(II) MOF materials with 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylate in a unusual coordination mode. A few examples of (4,4) layers with transition metal ions containing the bta4− group as a tetrakis-monodentate ligand have been reported and a selection of their relevant structural parameters are listed in Table . Although the number of reported structures is very small, one can see therein that the rectangular motif is the preferred one.

Although the number of reported structures is very small, one can see therein that the rectangular motif is the preferred one.

We would like to finish the structural description of 1–3 with a brief discussion about the versatility as a ligand of the partially or fully deprotonated forms of the pyromellitic acid (H4bta) in its cobalt(II) complexes in the absence of coligands and as a function of the different synthetic routes which have been used. This information is summarized in Table . One can see therein how the mild (slow evaporation and slow diffusion) and hard (hydrothermal synthesis) reaction/medium conditions exert a great influence on the structures of the resulting pyromellitate-containing cobalt(II) complexes. This table illustrates well the richness of the coordination chemistry (variable dimensionality networks and polymorphism) of the deprotonated forms of the H4bta ligands and offers a rare opportunity to examinate the role of several reaction parameters on the structure of the isolated compound.

The magnetic properties of the complexes 2 and 3 under the form of χM T against T plot [χM is the magnetic susceptibility per mol of cobalt(II) ions] are shown in Figures and . The magnetic curve of 1 is identical to that of 2, and consequently we will not refer to it hereunder. At room temperature, the values of χM T are 2.87 (2) and 2.84 cm3 mol−1 K (3) [μeff per Co(II) = 4.79 (2) and 4.77 μB (3) to be compared with μeff (spin-only, g = 2) = 3.87μB]. These values are within the range of those observed for systems containing a six-coordinated high-spin cobalt(II) ion with unquenched angular momentum. Upon cooling, the values of χM T decrease to 1.67 and 1.47 cm3 mol-1 K at 1.9 K, for 2 and 3, respectively. No maximum of the magnetic susceptibility is observed in the corresponding χM versus T plots. The decrease of χM T in 1−3 can be due to an antiferromagnetic interaction between the cobalt(II) ions and/or to the depopulation of the higher energy Kramers doublets of the cobalt(II) centers. Given the large intralayer cobalt−cobalt separation in 1−3 (values of ca. 6.7 Å through the adjacent carboxylate-bta groups), the magnetic interaction between the local spin quartets, if any, is expected to be very weak. Consequently, the magnetic behavior of 1−3 is essentially due to magnetically isolated high-spin Co(II) ions.

Magnetic Properties of 1-3 

The magnetic properties of the complexes 2 and 3 under the form of χM T against T plot [χM is the magnetic susceptibility per mol of cobalt(II) ions] are shown in Figures  and . The magnetic curve of 1 is identical to that of 2, and consequently we will not refer to it hereunder. At room temperature, the values of χM T are 2.87 (2) and 2.84 cm3 mol-1 K (3) [μeff per Co(II) = 4.79 (2) and 4.77 μB (3) to be compared with μeff (spin-only, g = 2) = 3.87μB]. These values are within the range of those observed for systems containing a six-coordinated high-spin cobalt(II) ion with unquenched angular momentum. Upon cooling, the values of χM T decrease to 1.67 and 1.47 cm3 mol-1 K at 1.9 K, for 2 and 3, respectively. No maximum of the magnetic susceptibility is observed in the corresponding χM versus T plots. The decrease of χM T in 1-3 can be due to an antiferromagnetic interaction between the cobalt(II) ions and/or to the depopulation of the higher energy Kramers doublets of the cobalt(II) centers. Given the large intralayer cobalt-cobalt separation in 1-3 (values of ca. 6.7 Å through the adjacent carboxylate-bta groups), the magnetic interaction between the local spin quartets, if any, is expected to be very weak. Consequently, the magnetic behavior of 1-3 is essentially due to magnetically isolated high-spin Co(II) ions.

elements.content: A high-spin cobalt(II) ion in Oh symmetry has a 4T1g ground-state which is well separated from the single-ion excited states, the thermal population at room temperature of these excited levels being negligible. Spin−orbit coupling splits the 4T1g low-lying state into a sextet, a quartet, and a Kramers doublet, the corresponding Hamiltonian being defined by H so = −αλLS with α = Aκ, where A is a parameter whose value depends on the strength of the crystal field [its value varies between 3/2 (weak crystal field) and 1 (strong crystal field) in cobalt(II) complexes], k is the orbital reduction factor, and λ is the spin−orbit coupling constant. Under an axial distortion on the six-coordinated high-spin cobalt(II) ion (being approximately C 4), the triplet orbital 4T1g ground-state splits into singlet 4 A 2 and doublet 4E levels with a Δ energy gap. The one-center operator responsible for this axial distortion can be expressed as H ax = Δ[L 2 z − 1/3L(L + 1)]. In the light of these considerations, we have analyzed the magnetic data of 1−3 through the Hamiltonian of eq H = − α λ LS + Δ [ L z 2 − 1 / 3 L ( L + 1 ) ] + β ( − α L + g e S ) H where the last term accounts for the Zeeman interaction. In the frame of T 1g and P terms isomorphism, L(T 1g) = −A L(P), we can use L = 1 and to treat (1) as an Hamiltonian describing the interaction between two angular moments L = 1 and S = 3/2, being −αλ the coupling parameter and Δ the zero-field splitting of the triplet L = 1. On the basis of the lack of an analytical expression for the magnetic susceptibility as a function of the parameters A, κ, λ and Δ, their values were determined through numerical matrix diagonalization techniques. Prior to that and in order to avoid overparametrization, several fits were tempted with fixed values of A, the best fit being achieved for A = 1.48 (2) and 1.40 (3). It deserves to be noted that these values are as expected, taking into account that the cobalt(II) surroundings in 1−3 correspond to the weak field case. The set of parameters for 2 and 3 obtained by the corresponding fits are the following: κ = 0.95, α = 1.41, λ = −96 cm−1, Δ = −1030 cm−1, θ = −0.65 K and R = 9.1 × 10−5 (2) and κ = 0.89, α = 1.24, λ = −131 cm−1, Δ = −790 cm−1, θ = −0.60 K and R = 8.6 × 10−5 (3), where θ is a Curie−Weiss term accounting for the weak magnetic coupling between the paramagnetic centers and R is the agreement factor defined as ∑[(χM T)obs − (χM T)calc]2/∑[(χM T)obs]2. The theoretical curves reproduce well the experimental data in the whole temperature range, as shown in Figures and .

elements.content: The weak antiferromagnetic interactions in 2 and 3, J′ = −0.09 (2) and −0.08 cm−1 (3), [values calculated through the known expression zJ′ = 3kθ/S(S + 1) where z = 4 (number of neighbors) and S = 1/2 (effective spin of the ground Kramers doublet of the high-spin cobalt(II) ion)] confirm our assumption dealing with the weak magnetic coupling expected through the extended bta4− bridges and support the approach used to analyze their magnetic properties. The values of κ in 2 and 3 are within the range of those reported for octahedral cobalt(II) ions surrounded by six oxygen atoms. As far as for the values of λ are concerned, they are somewhat smaller than that of the free ion (λo = −180 cm−1) due to covalence effects. Finally, the negative values of the energy gap Δ indicate that the orbital doublet 4 E is the ground term. Although the sign of Δ is hard to determine by the fit of magnetic data of polycrystalline samples, a positive value for Δ in the present family gives significantly lower quality fits.

elements.content: Having in mind the data of Table , the main advantages and drawbacks of these preparative methods can be briefly outlined. The hydrothermal synthesis is commonly used in the last several years, the increasing interest in this technique being essentially due to the high reactivity of the reactants (because of the high values of the temperature and pressure involved), easy control of the starting solutions (variability of pH, solvents, etc.), the access to metastable phases (which could not be obtained at room temperature) and a low energy consumption. The polymorphs which are obtained at two different temperatures are a clear example of the potentiality of this technique., Its main drawback is the difficulty of separating the targeted product from the resulting powder that often cocrystallizes. The alternative synthetic route to grow single crystals of highly insoluble polymers is the slow diffusion through liquid solvents (often water, common organic solvents or a mixture of them) or gel media. Again, the phases obtained through this technique may differ from those resulting from the traditional concentration through slow evaporation under ambient conditions. The main difficulty associated with the slow diffusion arises when different phases cocrystallize in the same region of the device given that the manual separation is quite tedious. Finally, it deserves to be outlined that the slow evaporation method is rarely used for the preparation of crystalline samples of bta-containing metal complexes because of the great ability of the polycarboxylate ligands to afford highly insoluble polymeric species.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Having in mind the data of Table , the main advantages and drawbacks of these preparative methods can be briefly outlined. The hydrothermal synthesis is commonly used in the last several years, the increasing interest in this technique being essentially due to the high reactivity of the reactants (because of the high values of the temperature and pressure involved), easy control of the starting solutions (variability of pH, solvents, etc.), the access to metastable phases (which could not be obtained at room temperature) and a low energy consumption. The polymorphs which are obtained at two different temperatures are a clear example of the potentiality of this technique., Its main drawback is the difficulty of separating the targeted product from the resulting powder that often cocrystallizes. The alternative synthetic route to grow single crystals of highly insoluble polymers is the slow diffusion through liquid solvents (often water, common organic solvents or a mixture of them) or gel media. Again, the phases obtained through this technique may differ from those resulting from the traditional concentration through slow evaporation under ambient conditions. The main difficulty associated with the slow diffusion arises when different phases cocrystallize in the same region of the device given that the manual separation is quite tedious. Finally, it deserves to be outlined that the slow evaporation method is rarely used for the preparation of crystalline samples of bta-containing metal complexes because of the great ability of the polycarboxylate ligands to afford highly insoluble polymeric species.

cln_elements.content:
Single crystals of 1 were grown by slow diffusion using the gel technique. An aqueous solution of NaOH (0.5 M) was added dropwise to another aqueous solution (5 cm3) of H4bta (0.127 g, 0.5 mmol) until a value of pH = 4.5 was reached. Then, tetramethoxysilane (0.25 cm3) was added to the previous solution under vigorous stirring. The gel was formed after standing 1 day at room temperature. An aqueous solution (3 cm3) of CoCl2·6H2O (0.119 g, 0.5 mmol) was carefully added over the gel. Prismatic pink crystals of 1 were grown at room temperature after several weeks. They were mechanically separated, washed with 50/50 water/methanol solution, and air-dried. Anal. Calcd. for C10H26Co2O20 (1): C, 17.11; H, 3.71. Found: C, 17.05; H, 3.67%.

[Co<sub>2</sub>(bta)(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>8</sub>]<italic toggle="yes"> <sub>n</sub> </italic>·2<italic toggle="yes">n</italic>H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>3</bold>)

Aqueous solutions of H4bta (0.12 g, 0.5 mmol) and sodium carbonate (0.10 g, 1 mmol) were mixed (total volume 55 cm3). The cobalt(II) chloride hexahydrate (0.119 g, 0.5 mmol) dissolved in a minimum amount of water was added to the previous solution under vigorous stirring. The resulting clear solution was allowed to evaporate under controlled temperature at ca. 50 °C. X-ray quality crystals of 3 as pink needles were obtained after two days. Anal. Calcd. for C10H22Co2O18 (3): C, 18.04; H, 3.30. Found: C, 17.95; H, 3.26%.

Synthesis of the Complexes

[Co2(bta)(H2O)8] n ⋅4nH2O (1)

Single crystals of 1 were grown by slow diffusion using the gel technique. An aqueous solution of NaOH (0.5 M) was added dropwise to another aqueous solution (5 cm3) of H4bta (0.127 g, 0.5 mmol) until a value of pH = 4.5 was reached. Then, tetramethoxysilane (0.25 cm3) was added to the previous solution under vigorous stirring. The gel was formed after standing 1 day at room temperature. An aqueous solution (3 cm3) of CoCl2⋅6H2O (0.119 g, 0.5 mmol) was carefully added over the gel. Prismatic pink crystals of 1 were grown at room temperature after several weeks. They were mechanically separated, washed with 50/50 water/methanol solution, and air-dried. Anal. Calcd. for C10H26Co2O20 (1): C, 17.11; H, 3.71. Found: C, 17.05; H, 3.67%.

[Co2(bta)(H2O)8] n ⋅2nH2O (3)

Aqueous solutions of H4bta (0.12 g, 0.5 mmol) and sodium carbonate (0.10 g, 1 mmol) were mixed (total volume 55 cm3). The cobalt(II) chloride hexahydrate (0.119 g, 0.5 mmol) dissolved in a minimum amount of water was added to the previous solution under vigorous stirring. The resulting clear solution was allowed to evaporate under controlled temperature at ca. 50 °C. X-ray quality crystals of 3 as pink needles were obtained after two days. Anal. Calcd. for C10H22Co2O18 (3): C, 18.04; H, 3.30. Found: C, 17.95; H, 3.26%.

This compound was obtained by following a procedure similar to that used for 1 but changing the pH to 5.0. Prismatic pink crystals of 2 were formed after a few weeks on standing at room temperature. They were mechanically separated, washed with a 50/50 water/methanol solution, and air-dried. Anal. Calcd. for C10H26Co2O20 (2): C, 17.11; H, 3.71. Found: C, 17.04; H, 3.68%.

[Co<sub>2</sub>(bta)(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>8</sub>]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub>·4<italic toggle="yes">n</italic>H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>2</bold>)

The structure of 2 consists of two crystallographically independent parallel (4,4) square grid layers that grow in the bc crystallographic plane similar to that observed in 1. In fact, 2 and 1 are polymorphs. They are built up by fully deprotonated bta4− anions acting as 4-fold connectors and [Co(H2O)4]2+ cations acting as linear nodes (Figure a). The layers are stacked along the a direction following the ABAB sequence, leading to the formation of pores of dimension 11.483(3) × 11.329(5) Å2 [defined by the distance between adjacent cobalt atoms within the two layers]. The total potential solvent accessible void volume is 274.0 Å3 which represents a 25.3% of the unit cell. The distance between adjacent layers is 5.4235(10) Å, a value which is similar to that observed for compound 1. The layers are interconnected through extensive hydrogen bonds involving some of the carboxylate-oxygen atoms, and the coordination and the crystallization water molecules (see end of Table ) to afford a 3D supramolecular network Figure b).
